name: will.i.am
description:
'''William Adams''' (born March 15, 1975), known professionally as '''will.i.am''' (pronounced "will I am"), is an American rapper, singer, and record producer, best known as the frontman of the musical group [[Black Eyed Peas]] — which he formed with fellow rappers [[apl.de.ap]] and [[Taboo (rapper)|Taboo]] in 1995. The group has released nine studio albums, and saw their highest success with the [[pop rap]] albums ''[[Elephunk]]'' (2003), ''[[Monkey Business (Black Eyed Peas album)|Monkey Business]]'' (2005), ''[[The E.N.D.]]'' (2009), and ''[[The Beginning (Black Eyed Peas album)|The Beginning]]'' (2010), during which he shared lead vocals with fellow singer [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]].

As a solo artist, Adams signed with [[Atlantic Records]] to release his debut album ''[[Lost Change]]'' (2001), and later [[Barely Breaking Even]] to release his second album ''[[Must B 21]]'' (2003), both of which failed to chart. The latter contained the song "Go!", which served as theme music for ''[[NBA Live 2005]]'' and ''[[Madden NFL 2005]]''. After gaining success with the Black Eyed Peas, he signed with [[Interscope Records]] to release his third album, ''[[Songs About Girls]]'' (2007), which moderately entered the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] — becoming his first solo project to do so — and spawned the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]-top 40 single "[[I Got It From My Mama]]". His fourth album, ''[[willpower (will.i.am album)|#willpower]]'' (2013), peaked at number nine on the ''Billboard'' 200, and was supported by the ''Billboard'' Hot 100-top five hit, "[[Scream & Shout]]" (with [[Britney Spears]]). In addition, he guest appeared on Fergie's 2006 single "[[Fergalicious]]" and [[Usher (musician)|Usher]]'s 2010 single "[[OMG (Usher song)|OMG]]", which peaked at numbers two and one on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, respectively.

A prolific [[will.i.am production discography|record producer and songwriter]], Adams has amassed credits on releases for fellow [[music industry]] acts. These include  [[Michael Jackson]], [[Rihanna]], [[Miley Cyrus]], [[Kanye West]], [[Kendrick Lamar]], [[Chris Brown]], [[Jennifer Hudson]], [[U2]], [[Kesha]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Psy]], [[Justin Timberlake]], [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Estelle (musician)|Estelle]], [[Kid Cudi]], [[Nas]], [[Robin Thicke]], [[John Legend]], [[Cheryl (singer)|Cheryl]], and [[2NE1]], among others. From both his solo career and groupwork with the Black Eyed Peas, he has had 41 [[UK singles chart]]-top 40 entries since 1998, and has sold 9.4 million singles in the country. He founded a [[will.i.am Music Group|self-titled record label]] in 1998, which has signed artists including [[LMFAO]], [[Kelis]], and [[Macy Gray]].

Outside of music, Adams founded the technology company [[i.am+]] in 2013; he has also served as a panelist and mentor on the reality competition series ''[[The Voice UK]]'' (2012–present), [[The Voice (Australian TV series)|''The Voice Australia'']] (2014), and [[The Voice Kids (British TV series)|''The Voice Kids'']] (2017–2023). He is the recipient of seven [[Grammy Awards]], a [[Latin Grammy Award]], and a [[Daytime Emmy Award]].
